> I am loading up my list of test cases from an xml file with something 
> like class and method.  Then using class.forname and 
> class.newinstance I would instantiate the TestCase.  I then wanted to 
> call TestCase.setName and then add the testcase to the testsuite.  
> unfortunately the newInstance fails because TestCase has a default 
> constructor that is not public.  :(  Is there a particular reason why 
> this is so?


In JUnit 3.7: only the ctor with the String argument is allowed.  You 
should first retrieve this constructor from the class and create a new 
instance

In JUnit from the CVS repository: the non-arg TestCase ctor is now 
public.  Subclasses from TestCase can be directly created with a 
Instance() method and the name of the test to run has to be set with the 
setName() method.
